resources.string: Nirmalya aims to provide technology and strategy based interventions in currently practiced solutions to increase their acceptability, sustainability, provide improved quality of products and services and innovate novel domains of waste utilisation.\n\n Our vision is to establish a zero-waste society capable of dealing with waste management in a sustainable manner
Indian Institute Of Technology Delhi \n Hauz Khas, New Delhi-110 016
Nirmalya is a non-profit organisation under the registered trust, Enactus IIT Delhi.

"We present an Integrated Zero Waste Plan i.e Kalp wherein we deal with the horticultural and the wet waste of the society through composting techniques, both at community and decentralised levels. Our approach has the following facets:Baseline Study of awareness of people about Waste Management, Awareness programmes to encourage people to start at source segregation, Pit Composting for management of wet waste at community Level,Home Composter for management of wet waste at household level,Mesh Composting for management of horticulture waste at Community level, Empowerment and Inclusion of Gardeners, waste pickers and residents as stakeholders in the process.
"

Segregation is a very easy process, a small step that rewards our planet richly enabling complete management of waste, with wet waste being composted and dry waste being recycled. However, many of us are new to it, and may have some doubts regarding the process. Here are some commonly asked questions about waste segregation:
Why do I separate the wet waste from the dry waste?

It is important to do so because both these types of wastes are dealt with differently. Wet organic waste is converted into compost while dry waste such as paper, plastic, glass etc can be recycled. If the two wastes are mixed together, it is neither possible to compost the waste, nor can it be recycled.

Paper products, tetra packs, toothpaste cartons, cans, glass bottles, carry bags, milk packets, plastic and cardboard packaging material, food containers, PET bottles – basically any glass, plastic, paper or metal item that can be recycled is part of dry waste.
Vegetable peels, fruit peels, flowers, tea bags, coffee powder, coconut shell, fiber, egg shell etc.
What about old batteries, are those dry waste?

Used batteries are part of electronic waste which comes under the category of hazardous waste. This type of waste needs to be disposed separately since it contains toxic chemicals and substances.\n E-waste includes: CFL bulbs, tubelights, chargers, mobile or computer components, old batteries, CDs, cassettes or any other discarded electronic items.
Apart from E-waste, what other wastes can be hazardous?
These include old thermometers, used paint cans, pesticides, cleaning or caustic agents, used motor oil.
What about reject waste, what is that?

This is the waste which cannot be recycled or composted, and unlike hazardous waste no useful components can be extracted from it at all. This includes used sanitary pads, diapers, some kinds of medical waste, sewage wastes etc. These must be disposed separately from the dry and wet wastes.
How do I store milk packets for disposal once in a few days? Won’t there be a problem of flies coming on them?

Milk packets and other packaging material which was used to store food items should be emptied of their contents and then rinsed and dried before storage. Then there will be no problem of pests or bad odor.
What do I do with old clothes/ shoes/ handbags/belts/toys?

If they are still in usable condition, they should be given to some organization that collects them. If they are totally unusable, or very damaged, they are still categorized as dry waste. If clothes are soiled with body fluids, they become sanitary waste. If they are soiled with paint, or any chemicals, they are household hazardous waste.
What do I do with old crockery / non-stick pans etc?

If they are not broken, they are recyclable dry waste. If broken, debris or rubbish (inerts).
 The same is true for old furniture, old taps and sanitaryware.
